p: Although Ae. albopictus has a strong affinity for humans, it demonstrates a wide range of host preference [ 66, 67]. In the absence of humans, it will obtain blood meals from other mammals and non-mammal species including birds and reptiles [ 68]. In the albopictus model, we assumed that the number of eggs laid by female Ae. albopictus (fecundity) is independent of human population density [ 30]. In accordance with this, here, we assumed that fecundity and the number of human-vector interactions are independent quantities; Ae. albopictus will always find the blood meal it needs even if there are no humans around.
